Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experience for undergraduates interested in Materials Science and Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Helmerich Research Center at Oklahoma State University (OSU) offers research experiences in materials science and engineering research to a diverse group of talented students over a period of three years. The student research projects focus on materials processing, testing and characterization for interdisciplinary applications in energy storage, energy generation, biomaterials, combustion, and aerospace. In addition, students are introduced to entrepreneurship and commercialization to transition research from the lab-scale to the real world, thus enhancing U.S. competitiveness. Students are recruited from Oklahoma colleges and universities that have limited STEM research facilities and large populations of students underrepresented in STEM. The program is leveraging existing OSU's partnerships with Tulsa Community College, which is a feeder program for Native American students transferring to undergraduate engineering programs at OSU and the Oklahoma Louis Stoke Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) to identify a diverse pool of student applicants.

The REU Site offers opportunities to undergraduate students to engage in in-depth research experiences in several areas of advanced manufacturing in aerospace, energy and biomaterials. During the 9-week experience, students are mentored by experienced faculty to conduct materials engineering and science research projects in: 3-D printing and direct digital manufacturing, materials processing, and materials testing and characterization. The students are also: learning about cutting-edge materials characterization methods (through web-based participation in the two-day national workshop on Advanced Materials Characterization offered by the Materials Research Laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign); exposed to entrepreneurial routes to commercializing research (in collaboration with the Riata Center of Entrepreneurship); participating in a professional development program that includes training in communications skills and graduate school preparation and career information sessions; presenting their research results at a research symposium at the end of the summer; and being provided with opportunities to interact with local industry partners (in Tulsa, OK) that are engaged in materials research.

This REU Site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU program has been a grand success. A total of 32 undergraduate students from different parts of the country have participated in this program over the three years. These students have come from varied academic backgrounds including biomedical engineering, mechanical engineering, chemical engineering, chemistry, physics, innovation and entrepreneurship, bioengineering and biotechnology. In addition, students from top ranked undergraduate materials science and engineering programs in the country have also participated. Each REU scholar conducted research on a project in core materials science and engineering and/or an interdisciplinary project with a strong footprint in materials research. These students were provided a comprehensive research experience in materials science and engineering and its strong interdisciplinary nature. This included (a) learning the process of research, (b) introduction to resources for conducting research including bibliographic search and tools, and experimental methods for materials characterization, (c) opportunities and training to identify the specific research questions towards project objectives, (d) conducting hands-on research including experimentation and analysis, and (e) presentation of scientific findings of research to diverse audience. Besides, the REU scholars were also introduced to research in industry, defense organizations, and provided opportunities to interact with entrepreneurs, and other REU scholars in ongoing NSF-REU programs at OSU. Annual programs culminated with a poster competition and commencement ceremony. Several REU scholars have communicated their plans to pursue graduate studies in engineering.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merits of the program were significant despite the limited 9-week curriculum and has resulted in several national/international conference presentations and archival publications (a few are still being finalized). The scientific outcomes of some of the projects have also translated in development of stronger research proposals by the participating faculty mentors for submission to federal and state agencies. 

Besides the above, the REU program also offers a unique insight into the impact of introducing undergraduate students to interdisciplinary research. These scholars came from diverse academic backgrounds, and were unbiased by any prior research training. Keeping track of their career choices and professional growth in the next five years, as proposed in the project, will provide an unparalleled opportunity to gauge the true impact of introducing young scientists to interdisciplinary research. We strongly believe that this will be critical for grooming of the next generation of scientists and engineers who can effectively work in large teams required to pursue convergence-based research for grand challenges.

This REU project has established that we can educate and motivate undergraduate re-searcher participants to pursue materials research-based career options in graduate studies, in indus-try as well as consider entrepreneurship. Our two primary target populations included students from female groups, primarily undergraduate institutions and under-represented groups. In our previous REU site, we had reasonable success in recruiting from these populations. Specifically, 28% of our fellows were from under-represented groups, 28% were female and 22% were from primarily under-graduate institutions, 100% of students who graduated are employed in STEM related fields while all students pursuing graduate school are enrolled in MSE programs; of the remaining, 95% are planning to pursue advanced degrees at various institutions, whose interest in graduate studies was enhanced due to their involvement in the REU program. To increase these numbers, we will enhance our existing partnerships with Tulsa Community College, a feeder program for Native American stu-dents with an associate degree transferring to the undergraduate engineering programs at OSU and the Oklahoma Louis Stoke Alliance for Minority Participation to identify and enhance the number of student applicants, especially from underrepresented groups. We will also strengthen our entrepreneurship component by leveraging the OSU I-Corps site program.

Broader Impacts: One of the significant impacts of this REU program was in grooming undergraduate engineering and science students to pursue interdisciplinary research with a strong-base in materials science and engineering. We believe that this is critical for developing a workforce to address global grand challenges in energy, aerospace, medicine, environmental sustainability and maintain technological leadership position of the US in the 21st century. This REU site served to educate and motivate undergraduate researcher participants to pursue materials-research based career options in graduate studies, in industry as well as become entrepreneurs at a young age. The participating stu-dents were recruited from a pool of applicants nationwide with an emphasis on recruiting under-represented minority students. We leveraged our existing partnerships with the Tulsa Community College, a feeder program for Native American students with an associate degree transferring to the undergraduate engineering programs at OSU and the Oklahoma Louis Stoke Alliance for Minority Participation to identify a diverse pool of student applicants. Additionally, undergraduate students were able to appreciate the linkage between what they learned in the laboratories and applied it to practical problem solving.
